title: Psalms Chapter 135 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 135 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 135 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 135.

questions.question: Who does Psalms 135:1 call to praise the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: The servants of the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:1 specifically calls 'O ye servants of the LORD' to praise the name of the LORD.

questions.question: Where does Psalms 135:2 say the people stand to praise the LORD?
options: In the house of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: In the house of the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:2 mentions standing 'in the house of the LORD, in the courts of the house of our God'.

questions.question: According to Psalms 135:3, why should we sing praises to the LORD's name?
options: Because the LORD is good and pleasing
Because the LORD is mighty and strong
questions.correctAnswer: Because the LORD is good and pleasing
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:3 states 'Praise the LORD; for the LORD is good: sing praises unto his name; for it is pleasant.'

questions.question: Who has the LORD chosen for Himself according to Psalms 135:4?
questions.correctAnswer: Jacob and Israel
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:4 says, 'For the LORD hath chosen Jacob unto himself, and Israel for his peculiar treasure.'

questions.question: What does Psalms 135:5 say about the LORD's greatness?
options: The LORD is great and above all gods
The LORD is small but mighty
The LORD is equal to the gods
The LORD is unknown to many
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD is great and above all gods
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:5 declares, 'For I know that the LORD is great, and that our Lord is above all gods.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 135:6 says the LORD did whatever He pleased only on earth.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:6 states the LORD did whatsoever He pleased 'in heaven, and in earth, in the seas, and all deep places', not just on earth.

questions.question: According to Psalms 135:7, what does the LORD cause to ascend from the ends of the earth?
questions.correctAnswer: The vapours
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:7 says, 'He causeth the vapours to ascend from the ends of the earth; he maketh lightnings for the rain; he bringeth the wind out of his treasuries.'

questions.question: Who did the LORD smite according to Psalms 135:8?
questions.correctAnswer: The firstborn of Egypt
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:8 states, 'Who smote the firstborn of Egypt, both of man and beast.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 135:9 describes the LORD sending wonders upon Pharaoh and his servants.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:9 says, 'Who sent tokens and wonders into the midst of thee, O Egypt, upon Pharaoh, and upon all his servants.'

questions.question: Which kings are mentioned as being smitten by the LORD in Psalms 135:11?
options: Sihon king of the Amorites and Og king of Bashan
Pharaoh king of Egypt and Nebuchadnezzar
David king of Israel and Saul
Cyrus king of Persia and Darius
questions.correctAnswer: Sihon king of the Amorites and Og king of Bashan
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:11 names 'Sihon king of the Amorites, and Og king of Bashan, and all the kingdoms of Canaan' as smitten by the LORD.

questions.question: What did the LORD give Israel as an heritage according to Psalms 135:12?
questions.correctAnswer: The land of their enemies
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:12 says the LORD 'gave their land for an heritage, an heritage unto Israel his people.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 135:13 states that the LORD's name will endure forever.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:13 declares, 'Thy name, O LORD, endureth for ever; and thy memorial, O LORD, throughout all generations.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 135:15, what are the idols of the heathen made of?
questions.correctAnswer: Silver and gold
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:15 says, 'The idols of the heathen are silver and gold, the work of men's hands.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Psalms 135:16: 'They have mouths, but they ______ not.'
questions.correctAnswer: speak
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:16 says, 'They have mouths, but they speak not; eyes have they, but they see not;'.

questions.question: Who does Psalms 135:19 call to bless the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: The house of Israel
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:19 says, 'Bless the LORD, O house of Israel: bless the LORD, O house of Aaron:'.

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 135 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 135 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Psalms 135, what biblical truth would you share about God's power over all things?
options: God controls the heavens, earth, seas, and every deep place.
God only watches over the righteous.
God's power is limited to the heavens.
God is unaware of human struggles.
questions.correctAnswer: God controls the heavens, earth, seas, and every deep place.
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:6 affirms that God does whatsoever He pleases in heaven, earth, seas, and all deep places, showing His sovereign power over all creation. Verses 7 and 10 also emphasize His control over natural elements and nations.

questions.question: How does Psalms 135 teach us about the importance of praising God in our daily lives?
options: We should praise God continually because He is good and His name is to be honored.
Praising God is optional and only for special occasions.
Praising God is only for priests and Levites.
Praise is meant only for personal benefit.
questions.correctAnswer: We should praise God continually because He is good and His name is to be honored.
questions.explanation: Verses 1-3 emphasize praising the LORD, declaring His goodness and the pleasantness of singing praises to His name. This encourages ongoing devotion and gratitude.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with trusting God in their work. Based on Psalms 135, what truth about God's providence can you share?
options: God causes the winds and rain to come from His treasuries.
God only provides for spiritual needs, not material ones.
God is distant from daily work.
questions.correctAnswer: God causes the winds and rain to come from His treasuries.
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:7 teaches that God controls natural forces like wind and rain, symbolizing His provision and care over the earth and our daily lives, including work and sustenance.

questions.question: How does Psalms 135 present the value of obedience and faithfulness in family and community life?
options: God chose Jacob and Israel as His special treasure, highlighting covenant faithfulness.
Obedience is unnecessary for God's favor.
Family loyalty is more important than obedience to God.
God favors only the wealthy families.
questions.correctAnswer: God chose Jacob and Israel as His special treasure, highlighting covenant faithfulness.
questions.explanation: Verse 4 states that the LORD chose Jacob and Israel as His peculiar treasure, showing that obedience and faithfulness to God are foundational for family and community identity.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged by the power of false idols around them. What biblical insight from Psalms 135 can encourage them about trusting God?
options: Idols have mouths but cannot speak, eyes but cannot see, and have no breath.
Idols are powerful and should be respected.
Idols can answer prayers if worshiped correctly.
questions.correctAnswer: Idols have mouths but cannot speak, eyes but cannot see, and have no breath.
questions.explanation: Verses 15-17 describe idols as lifeless objects made by human hands that cannot hear, see, speak, or breathe, reinforcing trust in the living God alone.

questions.question: How does Psalms 135 encourage believers to maintain integrity and trust in God rather than in man-made things?
options: Those who make idols and trust in them are like the idols themselves.
Trusting in idols is wise because they are powerful.
Integrity comes from wealth and possessions.
Trusting in man-made things leads to prosperity.
questions.correctAnswer: Those who make idols and trust in them are like the idols themselves.
questions.explanation: Verse 18 teaches that people who create and trust idols become like them—lifeless and powerless—highlighting the importance of integrity in trusting God alone.

questions.question: What does Psalms 135 teach about God’s justice and care for His people when they face difficulties?
options: The LORD judges His people and has compassion on His servants.
God ignores the troubles of His people.
Justice belongs only to earthly kings.
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD judges His people and has compassion on His servants.
questions.explanation: Verse 14 explains that God judges His people righteously and repents (shows mercy) concerning His servants, offering hope in trials.

questions.question: How can Psalms 135 inspire believers to live with gratitude and contentment?
options: Because God’s name endures forever and His memorial is throughout all generations.
Because life is uncertain and people should only rely on themselves.
questions.correctAnswer: Because God’s name endures forever and His memorial is throughout all generations.
questions.explanation: Verse 13 emphasizes the eternal nature of God's name and remembrance, encouraging believers to cultivate gratitude and contentment in His unchanging character.

questions.question: A believer is wondering how to serve effectively in church life. Based on Psalms 135, what is the proper posture for those who fear the LORD?
options: They should bless the LORD with praise and thanksgiving.
They should focus only on personal blessings.
They should remain silent during worship.
They should serve only for recognition.
questions.correctAnswer: They should bless the LORD with praise and thanksgiving.
questions.explanation: Verses 19-20 call on the house of Israel, Aaron, Levi, and all who fear the LORD to bless Him, showing that worship and blessing God is central to church life and service.

questions.question: How does Psalms 135 demonstrate God’s faithfulness in fulfilling promises related to inheritance and stewardship?
options: He gave the lands of defeated kings as heritage to Israel.
He allows people to keep land through their own strength.
questions.correctAnswer: He gave the lands of defeated kings as heritage to Israel.
questions.explanation: Verses 11-12 describe how God gave the lands of Sihon, Og, and the kingdoms of Canaan as inheritance to Israel, illustrating divine faithfulness and the importance of stewardship.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 135, God’s name and memorial will last only for a few generations.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:13 states that God’s name endures forever and His memorial continues throughout all generations, emphasizing His eternal nature.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 135 teaches that God’s servants should trust in idols since they are crafted from silver and gold.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verses 15-18 explain that idols are lifeless objects made by human hands and those who trust in them are like them, teaching believers to trust in God alone.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "Praise ye the LORD; for the LORD is ______: sing praises unto his name; for it is pleasant."
questions.correctAnswer: good
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:3 states that the LORD is good, encouraging believers to praise Him joyfully because His goodness is pleasant.

questions.question: How does Psalms 135 instruct believers about humility and reverence before God?
options: Acknowledging that the LORD is above all gods and great.
questions.correctAnswer: Acknowledging that the LORD is above all gods and great.
questions.explanation: Verse 5 declares the LORD’s greatness and supremacy over all gods, encouraging believers to humble themselves and revere God’s authority.

questions.question: A believer wants to share the Gospel and testify about God’s mighty acts. What example from Psalms 135 would be most encouraging?
options: God sent wonders and smote great nations and kings to fulfill His promises.
God only works in secret and never reveals Himself.
God abandons His people in difficult times.
God’s acts are irrelevant to today’s believers.
questions.correctAnswer: God sent wonders and smote great nations and kings to fulfill His promises.
questions.explanation: Verses 9-11 describe God’s mighty acts against Egypt and other nations, demonstrating His power and faithfulness, a strong foundation for sharing the Gospel.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 135 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 135.

questions.question: In Psalms 135, what is the primary reason given for praising the LORD according to verse 3?
options: Because the LORD is mighty in battle
Because the LORD created the heavens
questions.correctAnswer: Because the LORD is good
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:3 states, 'Praise the LORD; for the LORD is good: sing praises unto his name; for it is pleasant,' emphasizing the goodness of the LORD as the reason for praise.

questions.question: Which two kings are specifically mentioned as being smitten by the LORD in Psalms 135?
options: Sihon king of the Amorites and Og king of Bashan
David king of Israel and Saul king of Israel
Cyrus king of Persia and Darius
questions.correctAnswer: Sihon king of the Amorites and Og king of Bashan
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:11 explicitly mentions 'Sihon king of the Amorites, and Og king of Bashan,' as kings whom the LORD smote.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 135, idols made by human hands have the ability to see and hear.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:16-17 states that idols have eyes but see not, ears but hear not, emphasizing their inability to perceive or respond.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: The LORD causes the vapors to ascend from the ends of the earth, makes lightnings for the rain, and brings the wind out of his ______.
questions.correctAnswer: treasuries
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:7 describes God's control over nature, stating He brings the wind out of his treasuries, symbolizing divine sovereignty over natural forces.

questions.question: According to Psalms 135, why has the LORD chosen Jacob and Israel?
options: To make them rulers over other nations
questions.correctAnswer: As his peculiar treasure
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:4 states that the LORD chose Jacob and Israel 'for his peculiar treasure,' indicating a special covenant relationship.

questions.question: How does Psalms 135 describe the duration and remembrance of God's name and memorial?
options: Lasts only for a single lifetime
Is recorded only in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Endures forever through all generations
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:13 declares, 'Thy name, O LORD, endureth for ever; and thy memorial, O LORD, throughout all generations,' emphasizing eternal remembrance.

questions.question: Which theme in Psalms 135 is typologically connected with God's control over nature as seen throughout Scripture?
questions.correctAnswer: Divine sovereignty over creation
questions.explanation: Verses like Psalms 135:6-7 highlight God's sovereign control of heaven, earth, seas, rain, and wind, a theme echoed in Genesis and throughout prophetic literature.

questions.question: Which houses or groups are called to bless the LORD in Psalms 135:19-20?
options: House of Israel, house of Aaron, and house of Levi
questions.correctAnswer: House of Israel, house of Aaron, and house of Levi
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:19-20 specifically calls upon 'house of Israel,' 'house of Aaron,' and 'house of Levi' to bless the LORD, reflecting a liturgical context.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used in Psalms 135:16-18 in describing idols and those who trust in them?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism and simile
questions.explanation: Verses 16-18 use parallelism by repeating the attributes idols lack and conclude with a simile comparing makers and trusters to the idols themselves.

questions.question: Which verse in Psalms 135 alludes to the Exodus event of the firstborn being struck?
questions.correctAnswer: Psalms 135:8
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:8 references God smiting the firstborn of Egypt, both man and beast, recalling the tenth plague in Exodus 12.

questions.question: The phrase 'he will repent himself concerning his servants' in Psalms 135:14 primarily refers to what aspect of God's character?
questions.correctAnswer: God's justice and mercy
questions.explanation: The word 'repent' here conveys God's compassionate adjustment in judgment, showing both justice and mercy toward His people.

questions.question: How does Psalms 135 depict the LORD's actions in heaven, earth, seas, and deep places in verse 6?
options: He is limited by other gods
He is inactive in these realms
questions.correctAnswer: He does whatsoever pleases Him
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:6 states that 'Whatsoever the LORD pleased, that did he in heaven, and in earth, in the seas, and all deep places,' affirming divine sovereignty.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the historical context behind the LORD giving the land of Canaan as an heritage to Israel in Psalms 135:12?
options: The conquest and settlement period after the Exodus
The time of the Judges' failure
The building of the Second Temple
questions.correctAnswer: The conquest and settlement period after the Exodus
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:12 reflects God's promise and fulfillment during Israel's conquest of Canaan under Joshua after their deliverance from Egypt.

questions.question: What intertextual connection does the command to ‘Praise ye the LORD’ in Psalms 135:1 have with other biblical Psalms?
options: It parallels many Psalms that open with calls to praise God, such as Psalms 113 and 117
It is unique to Psalms 135 and has no parallels
It contradicts the lament style of most Psalms
It is borrowed from the wisdom literature of Proverbs
questions.correctAnswer: It parallels many Psalms that open with calls to praise God, such as Psalms 113 and 117
questions.explanation: The exhortation to praise in Psalms 135:1 is a common motif in the Psalter, connecting this Psalm with others that emphasize worship and praise.

questions.question: The description of idols as 'the work of men's hands' in Psalms 135:15 serves to emphasize which theological point?
options: Idols are powerless and lifeless compared to the living God
questions.correctAnswer: Idols are powerless and lifeless compared to the living God
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:15 highlights that idols are human creations lacking life and power, contrasting them with the living LORD.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 135 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 135 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 135, why are the servants of the LORD called to praise His name?
options: Because the LORD is good and His name is pleasant to praise
Because He is a distant God who does not intervene
Because the LORD is silent in heaven
questions.correctAnswer: Because the LORD is good and His name is pleasant to praise
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:1-3 calls the servants of the LORD to praise His name because the LORD is good and it is pleasant to sing praises to Him. This aligns with Old Testament teachings about God's goodness (Exodus 34:6), the call to praise (Psalm 100:4), and New Testament affirmation of God's goodness (James 1:17).

questions.question: What special relationship does the LORD have with Jacob and Israel according to Psalms 135?
options: He has chosen Jacob and Israel as His peculiar treasure
He has rejected Jacob and Israel for their sins
He remains neutral towards Jacob and Israel
He has made Jacob and Israel equal to the gods
questions.correctAnswer: He has chosen Jacob and Israel as His peculiar treasure
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:4 states that the LORD has chosen Jacob and Israel as His peculiar treasure, emphasizing God's covenantal election and special relationship, consistent with Deuteronomy 7:6 and Romans 11:28.

questions.question: What does Psalms 135 teach about the LORD’s sovereignty over creation?
options: He does whatever He pleases in heaven, earth, seas, and deep places
He is limited to only the heavens
He does not control natural phenomena
He relies on idols to govern the earth
questions.correctAnswer: He does whatever He pleases in heaven, earth, seas, and deep places
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:6 affirms God's sovereign control over all creation, doing whatever pleases Him, consistent with Job 42:2, Isaiah 45:7, Colossians 1:16, and Revelation 4:11.

questions.question: In Psalms 135, what natural phenomena does the LORD control as demonstrations of His power?
options: Vapors, lightning for rain, and wind from His treasuries
The movement of stars but not the weather
questions.correctAnswer: Vapors, lightning for rain, and wind from His treasuries
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:7 describes the LORD’s control over vapors, lightning, and wind, showing His power over weather, consistent with Job 37:1-13, Jeremiah 10:13, and Matthew 8:26.

questions.question: Which judgments on Egypt are recalled in Psalms 135 as evidence of God’s power?
options: The smiting of the firstborn and sending tokens and wonders upon Pharaoh and his servants
The destruction of the Temple in Egypt
The drought in Egypt lasting seven years
The exile of Egyptians to Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: The smiting of the firstborn and sending tokens and wonders upon Pharaoh and his servants
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:8-9 recounts God's judgment on Egypt, including the death of the firstborn and plagues, aligning with Exodus 11:5 and 12:29 and showcasing God's power to deliver His people.

questions.question: Which kings and nations did the LORD defeat to give their land to Israel according to Psalms 135?
options: Sihon king of the Amorites, Og king of Bashan, and the kingdoms of Canaan
Pharaoh of Egypt and Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: Sihon king of the Amorites, Og king of Bashan, and the kingdoms of Canaan
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:10-12 names these kings and nations defeated by the LORD, illustrating His fulfillment of the promise to give the land to Israel, consistent with Numbers 21:21-35 and Joshua 12.

questions.question: What does Psalms 135 declare about the endurance of the LORD’s name and memorial?
options: The LORD’s name endures forever and His memorial throughout all generations
The LORD’s name will be forgotten after a time
The LORD’s memorial is only for a single generation
The LORD’s name changes with the seasons
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD’s name endures forever and His memorial throughout all generations
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:13 emphasizes the eternal nature of God's name and memorial, which aligns with Exodus 3:15, Isaiah 40:8, Hebrews 13:8, and Revelation 1:8.

questions.question: According to Psalms 135, how will the LORD respond to His people and servants?
options: He will judge His people and repent concerning His servants
He will abandon them in times of trouble
He will treat them as idols
questions.correctAnswer: He will judge His people and repent concerning His servants
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:14 teaches that the LORD judges His people but also shows mercy by repenting concerning His servants, consistent with Exodus 32:14, Jonah 3:10, 2 Chronicles 7:14, and 1 John 1:9.

questions.question: What does Psalms 135 say about the idols of the heathen?
options: They are silver and gold, made by men's hands and cannot speak, see, or hear
They are living gods with power to save
They are more powerful than the LORD
They are spiritual beings sent from heaven
questions.correctAnswer: They are silver and gold, made by men's hands and cannot speak, see, or hear
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:15-17 describes idols as lifeless objects made by human hands, incapable of speech, sight, or hearing, consistent with Isaiah 44:9-20 and Habakkuk 2:18-19.

questions.question: How does Psalms 135 describe those who make and trust in idols?
options: They are like the idols themselves
They have greater understanding than the wise
They are secretly worshippers of the true God
questions.correctAnswer: They are like the idols themselves
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:18 states that those who make idols and trust in them are like the idols—lifeless and powerless, which is supported by Jeremiah 10:14 and Romans 1:22-23.

questions.question: Who does Psalms 135 specifically call upon to bless the LORD?
options: The house of Israel, the house of Aaron, the house of Levi, and those who fear the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: The house of Israel, the house of Aaron, the house of Levi, and those who fear the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:19-20 calls on the entire covenant community, including Israel, Aaron's priestly line, Levi's tribe, and all who fear the LORD, reflecting the communal call to worship found in Deuteronomy 27:9 and Hebrews 7:11.

questions.question: Where does Psalms 135 say the LORD dwells, from where He is blessed?
options: In Zion, which dwells at Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: In Zion, which dwells at Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:21 declares the LORD dwells in Zion, Jerusalem, the spiritual center of God's presence, consistent with 2 Chronicles 6:6, Isaiah 2:3, and Hebrews 12:22.

questions.question: What theological truth about God’s nature is highlighted by His ability to bring wind out of His treasuries in Psalms 135?
options: God’s providence and control over creation
God’s limitation to only spiritual matters
God’s delegation of power to idols
questions.correctAnswer: God’s providence and control over creation
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:7 speaks of God bringing wind from His treasuries, demonstrating His providential control over nature, which echoes Job 38:22-30 and Matthew 10:29-31.

questions.question: How does Psalms 135 relate God’s judgment with His mercy towards His servants?
options: God judges His people but also repents concerning His servants
God ignores His servants when judging
God’s judgment is arbitrary and unchangeable
questions.correctAnswer: God judges His people but also repents concerning His servants
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:14 shows a balance of divine justice and mercy, where God judges but also relents for His servants, consistent with Exodus 34:6-7, Jonah 4:2, and Lamentations 3:22-23.

questions.question: What apologetic point does Psalms 135 make concerning the powerlessness of idols?
options: Idols have mouths, eyes, and ears but cannot speak, see, or hear
Idols perform miracles greater than God
Idols are living gods who hear prayers
Idols created the heavens and the earth
questions.correctAnswer: Idols have mouths, eyes, and ears but cannot speak, see, or hear
questions.explanation: Psalms 135:15-17 argues that idols are lifeless and powerless despite their human-like features, which is a classic apologetic refutation of idolatry, supported by Isaiah 44:9-20 and Psalm 115:4-8.
